head.p: This catalogue covers 501 loose prints from the Stein Collection, Third Expedition, 1913-16 (Second series, large prints). The series can be broken down chronologically as follows:

msItem.title: View up Nyachut from debouchure of Ishkobar Valley.
Panorama from above Dalgin (12,500') (Section III). View towards Barai and Babusar Passes.

note.p: Right-hand section of three-part panoramic view, continued in prints 11 and 12. Poor quality photograph, dark and indistinct. (I.A. Map A).

msItem.title: Panorama from Sheobat Pass (Section II). View to south. Range beyond Indus, head of Gayalgah.

note.p: India/Pakistan disputed territory; Kashmir; Sheobat Pass

msItem.title: Panorama from Sheobat Pass (Section I). To south-west, Sabil,

note.p: Right-hand section of two-part panoramic view, continued from print 3. Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 31: 'View from Sheobat Pass, looking south-west towards Tangir-Kandia watershed.'
India/Pakistan disputed territory; Kashmir; Sheobat Pass

msItem.title: View from Dalgin Marg towards Nanga Parbat.

note.p: View across wooded slopes towards distant peaks.

msItem.title: Nanga Parbat seen from above Dalgin (12,500'), across Khanbari and Hodur.
Nanga Parbat from Dalgin Camp.
Raja Shah Alim and Nizerat Khan, at Jaglot.
View from Dalgin towards Shkobar Pass.

note.p: View from meadow, looking over trees towards ridge.

msItem.title: Shah Alim and Nizerat Khan, Jaglot.

note.p: Group portrait of Raja, with attendants and Stein's dog Dash, in front of the castle walls. Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 25: 'Raja Pakhtun Wali's castle at Jaglot, Tangir. Mehtarjao Shah Alam seated in foreground.'

msItem.title: Panorama from above Dalgin (12,500') (Section II). Nanga Parbat seen from above Dalgin, across Khanbari Valley and Datsoi, Pakora.
Panorama from above Dalgin (12,500') (Section I). View towards upper Khanbari.
Ziarat of Shah Khel Baba, Phoguch.

note.p: General view of tomb building in carved wood. Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 30: 'Ziarat of Shaha-Khel Baba, built in carved timber, Poguch, Darel.' (I.A. Map A).

msItem.title: Shardai Pass panorama (Section III). Jaglot and continuation of Tangir (heavy forest).

note.p: India/Pakistan disputed territory; Kashmir; Shardai Pass

msItem.title: Shardai Pass panorama (Section II). Jaglot and continuation of Tangir (heavy forest).

note.p: India/Pakistan disputed territory; Kashmir; Shardai Pass

msItem.title: Sazin, Indus Valley and peaks above Indus bend, seen from spur (south) below Shardai Pass.

note.p: Poor quality image. Although not part of the panoramic view from the pass (prints 14, 15, 22), and taken from a slightly different view point, this image overlaps with and forms a continuation of print 22.
India/Pakistan disputed territory; Kashmir; Shardai Pass

msItem.title: Lohilo-kot with Phoguch below, seen from Shah Khel Ziarat.
Darel Valley seen from below Shardai Pass.

note.p: Poor quality image; view of distant mountains.
Darel Valley; India/Pakistan disputed territory; Kashmir

msItem.title: Ziarat at Dodo-kot (Shahid).

note.p: Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 28: 'Wood-carvings at Ziarat of Dodo-kot, Darel. Standing within arcade is Shahid of Papat.' Close view of tomb, showing richly-carved wooden arcade, with Shahid, commander of the supporters of the Pakhtun Wali. (I.A. Map A).

msItem.title: View down Darel Valley and across Indus from Lohilo-kot.

note.p: General view along valley. (I.A. Map A).

msItem.title: Shardai Pass, seen from south with upper Gayala-gah in background.

note.p: India/Pakistan disputed territory; Kashmir; Shardai Pass

msItem.title: Shardai Pass panorama (Section I). Indus bend, peaks, Swat Range.

note.p: India/Pakistan disputed territory; Kashmir; Shardai Pass

msItem.title: Interior of Lohilo-kot above Phoguch, seen from south-west corner.

note.p: View from hillside looking down onto fort remains. Cropped version of central area at Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 16: 'Remains of Lohilo-kot, below Poguch, Darel.' (I.A. Map A).

msItem.title: Gate of Dodo-kot, Samagial.

note.p: General view of gatehouse, with carved wooden architraves. Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 36: 'Gate of Dodo-kot village, Darel.' (I.A. Map A).

msItem.title: View up Yasin from Chumar khan; Dasht-i-taus in foreground.

note.p: 'Just to the north of Yasin and the mouth of the Nasbar valley there extends on the right bank an almost level plateau, about three miles long and one mile wide, known as Dasht-i-taus. It is known to local tradition to have once been cultivated, and its position is such as to permit of its easily being brought under irrigation again by a canal from the Nasbar stream.' (i, 43).
India/Pakistan disputed territory; Kashmir; Yasin Valley

msItem.title: Pakhtun Wali's castle, Jaglot, from across river.

note.p: General view looking towards the castle, with mountains beyond.

msItem.title: Raja of Hondur, Khushwakhs, with relatives and cultivators, Hondur, Yasin.

note.p: Posed group of eight men. Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 42: 'Group of Khushwaqts and Burish at Hondur, Yasin. Raja of Hondur (Khushwaqt) with two relatives, seated; behind, Burish cultivators.'

msItem.title: View down Yasin Valley from Chumarkhan.

note.p: Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 41: 'View down Yasin Valley from Chumarkhan. Rest-house near middle of view; castle behind it among trees.'
India/Pakistan disputed territory; Kashmir; Yasin Valley

msItem.title: Baipash of Jan Muhammad, Aksakal of Darkot.
View down Yasin Valley from Chumarkhan (underexposed).

note.p: India/Pakistan disputed territory; Kashmir; Yasin Valley

msItem.title: Darkot Pass from below Darband.

note.p: Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 44: 'Darkot Pass seen from below Barband Ridge.'
Darkot Pass; North-West Frontier Province; Pakistan

msItem.title: Pakhtun Wali's Castle, Jaglot, from river bank.

note.p: General view looking towards the stone perimeter walls.

msItem.title: Khuz Glacier from north-west. [Chapursan Valley.]

note.p: Chapursan; Hunza; India/Pakistan disputed territory; Kashmir; Khuz Glacier

msItem.title: End of (?) Khuz Glacier seen from above, south bank near Yarz-yarz.
Mountains east of Boihill lake bed, below Gul-khwaja, from south-west.

note.p: Lake bed and mountains at Boihill, south-west of the Mintaka Pass.

msItem.title: Men of Ashkuman, with Kurban Khan (Mehtarjao) and Havildar Kabul Beg at Biattur [Buattar].

note.p: A rather dark print. Group of twelve men, with Stein's dog Dash. Stein's negative notebook further identifies: Shasuf Beg, guide (standing on left); Wakhis from Ashkuman; Akhin Bai (sitting).

msItem.title: Ashkuman carriers, at Biattur [Buattur].

note.p: Similar to print 36, but group composed of porters only.

msItem.title: Derdi Gorge from west, below Kermin Pass.

note.p: View looking down into the gorge.

msItem.title: Khuz Glacier above tunnel.

note.p: Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 53: 'Glacier pushed across Karambar River below Shuiyenj.' 'About eight miles below the pass, the valley contracts below the last grazing grounds of Shuiyenj. Beyond this the track led past the snout of a large glacier on the south, which has piled its ice against the rocky slopes opposite. The river thus blocked had cut its way in a big tunnel below it.' (i, 50).

msItem.title: View from (?)Boihill towards Murkushi.

note.p: View looking south-west from Boihill towards distant peaks.

msItem.title: View across upper Mintaka Glacier (not entered in diary against [symbol] 7.9.13).

note.p: General view of glacier and mountains. Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 62: 'Head of Ming-taka Glacier, looking south-east from below pass.'
Hunza; India/Pakistan disputed territory; Kashmir; Mintaka Glacier; Mintaka Pass

msItem.title: Shigar-Ishkuk Glacier, Chaparsun, snout and streambed seen from south.

note.p: Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 64: 'Terminal portion of Ishkuk Glacier, Chapursan.'
Chapursan; Hunza; India/Pakistan disputed territory; Ishkuk Glacier; Kashmir

msItem.title: View from Chillinji Pass, 17,000', across Chillinji Glacier.

note.p: Chillinji Glacier; Chillinji Pass; Hunza; India/Pakistan disputed territory; Kashmir

msItem.title: Group of Wakhis in Reshit, Chaparsun.

note.p: Hunza; India/Pakistan disputed territory; Kashmir; Reshit

msItem.title: T.K. ruins (Afrazgul), Tughlan-shahr. T.K. IV from west (double exposure).
Tombs of Ihsans, Tughlan-shahr.

note.p: Distant view of tombs on a spur of rock. Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 71: 'Ridge with tombs of Ihsans, Toghlan-shahr.' (I.A. Map 3, C1).

msItem.title: Tashkurghan, T.K. I, II, seen from north-west (canal in fore). Stupa and small stupa base.
Muztagh-ata from Jurgal Gumbaz.

note.p: View towards Muztagh-ata mountains from Jurgal-gumbaz (not to be confused with the archaeological site of Jangal-gumbaz, to the north at Tash-kurghan). (I.A. Map 3, C1).

msItem.title: Muztagh-ata from Jurgal Gumbaz.
Muztagh-ata from Jurgal Gumbaz.
View across Sarikol from Taghash.

note.p: Very poor quality, indistinct image. (I.A. Map 3, C2).

msItem.title: Tash-kurghan ruins, T.K. III, from south-east [near Jangal-gumbaz].

note.p: General view of site, with river beyond. Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 70: 'Ruins near Jangal-gumbaz, above Tash-kurghan River.' (I.A. Map 3, C1). The site was not surveyed in detail by Stein: 'Owing to the late hour I was unable to examine it closely; but during my busy day at Tash-kurghan I had a plan and photograph of it taken by Surveyor Afraz-gul.' (i, 57).

msItem.title: Afrazgul, Muhammad Yakub and Shams Din at ?

note.p: Full-length standing portrait of three of Stein's assistants, posed in front of the mud wall of a house. Precise location unknown.

msItem.title: Lal-tagh ruins panorama (Section II).
Ruins of Lal-tagh, seen from south-west.
Ruin N. XLII from north [Niya site].

note.p: View looking towards site of house, with labourers at work. Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 98: 'Ruined dwelling, N. XLII, Niya site, seen from north in course of clearing.' (I.A. Map 19, B1).

msItem.title: N.XLII from tamarisk-cone to south-west [Niya site].

note.p: General view of site. Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 99: 'Site of ruin N. XLII, Niya site, seen from south-west before excavation.' (I.A. Map 19, B1).

msItem.title: N. III, ya-men and rooms to south-west, from north [Niya site].

note.p: Close view of remains of building, showing timber foundations and struts. With figure standing among the ruins to indicate scale. Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 97: 'North-western portion of ruined residence, N. III, Niya site, before final excavation.' (I.A. Map 19, B1).

msItem.title: Vineyard of N. XLIV (Afrazgul and Kharat) [Niya site].

note.p: General view of site, with Afgrazgul and Kharat in middleground. Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 132: 'Remains of ancient vineyard, with posts once carrying trellis, near N. XLIV, Niya site.' (I.A. Map 19, B1).

msItem.title: N. XLIV panorama (Section I). edge of depression. [Niya site.]

note.p: Right-hand section of two-part panoramic view, continued from print 63. Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 131: 'Panoramic view of wind-eroded ground near ruined structures, N. LXIV, Niya site. Remains of structures, N. XLIV, on terrace on right; ground occupied by ancient vineyard on extreme left.' (I.A. Map 19, B1).

msItem.title: Main ruins of Lal-tagh from south-west (Barat and Tokhta).

note.p: General view, with Barat and Tokhta standing in middleground. Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig 80: 'Ruins at Lal-tagh site, north-east of Maral-bashi.' (I.A. Map 7, B4).

msItem.title: Main ruins of Lal-tagh from south-west (Barat and Tokhta).
Ruin N. XLIII from south-west [Niya site].

note.p: View of part of site, with tamarisk cone in foreground. Not apparently listed in Stein's negative notebook. Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 94: 'Ruined dwelling, N. XLIII, Niya site, between tamarisk-cones, before excavation.' (I.A. Map 19, B1).

msItem.title: N. XLIV panorama (Section II). Continued to north-east.

note.p: Left-hand section of two-part panoramic view, continued in print 60. Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 131: 'Panoramic view of wind-eroded ground near ruined structures, N. LXIV, Niya site. Remains of structures, N. XLIV, on terrace on right; ground occupied by ancient vineyard on extreme left.' (I.A. Map 19, B1).

msItem.title: Lal-tagh panorama (Section I). From north-east (tower and mouth of recess).

note.p: Left-hand section of two-part panoramic view, continued in print 54. This print is not apparently listed in Stein's negative notebook, but is dateable from the adjoining section, which is. (I.A. Map 7, B4).

msItem.title: Panorama of interior of Fort L.K. (Section II).

note.p: Central section of three-part panoramic view, comprising prints 127, 129 and 131. Innermost Asia, vol. 1, fig. 133: 'Panoramic view of interior of ruined Fort L.K., Lop Desert, taken from north corner. Remains of dwelling I in centre; timber debris of completely eroded large structure, III, in foreground; on extreme left quarters iii, iv in course of excavation; wind-erorded terrace on right marks western corner of circumvallation.' (I.A. Map 29, D4).
China; Lop Desert (Stein Site L.K.); Xinjiang

'There, on a small fir-clad alp situated above a favourite Kirghiz camping ground at an elevation of over 10,000 feet, I was able to devote ten days of delightful coolness and seclusion to much hard work on reports, accounts, proposals about the collection of antiques, &c...' (ii, 844). (I.A. Map 2, C3).

msItem.title: Hale Beg and Yetmish Beg, Bostan-arche camp.

note.p: Group posed on hillside. (I.A. Map 2, C3).

note.p: General view along valley; Toghrasu not marked on Stein's map. Incorrectly dated 19 August in Stein's negative notebook. Variant of print 305. (I.A. Map 2, C2-3).

msItem.title: M. and Mad. Zampoin with Jigits and Goow. [at Daraut-kurghan].

note.p: Very poor quality image, dark and printed from a broken negative. Group of Zampoin, his wife and military officers. see note at print 376.

msItem.title: M. and Mad[ame] Zampoin [at Daraut-kurghan].

note.p: Full-length portrait of Zampoin, in uniform, seated, his wife standing behind him. A carpet hanging on the wall behind serves as a backdrop. Zampoin, referred to as 'the kindly Russian Customs Officer' (ii, 845), had met up with Stein at Por-dobe on 26 July, and they travelled together down the Alai Valley to Daraut-kurghan.

msItem.title: Trans-Alai panorama from Yaman-karchin (Section II). View to south.

msItem.title: Buruman, Yeshil-kol panorama. Panorama from southern slope (Section I). View to south towards spur from which barrier slid.

note.p: Poor quality print, uneven density. Right-hand section of two-part panoramic view, comprising prints 398 and 401. View looking towards scree and rubble on hillside, presumably the result of earthquake activity. 'To the eyes of the non-geologist the formation of the Buruman ridge closing the western end of the lake...seemed to bear a close resemblance to the newly formed barrage which has created the Sarez lake...' (ii, 857). Innermost Asia, vol. 2, fig. 381: 'Range facing Buruman ridge across western edge of Yeshil-kol.'

note.p: Left-hand section of two-part panoramic view, comprising prints 398 and 401. View looking towards scree and rubble on hillside, presumably the result of earthquake activity, with a small portion of the lake visible in the foreground. 'To the eyes of the non-geologist the formation of the Buruman ridge closing the western end of the lake...seemed to bear a close resemblance to the newly formed barrage which has created the Sarez lake...' (ii, 857). Innermost Asia, vol. 2, fig. 381: 'Range facing Buruman ridge across western edge of Yeshil-kol.'
